title: Getting Unstuck Day 8: Fish Chomp remix
description:
Seagull and clams from Creative Commons image search.

The Day 8 challenge reminded me of a student activity page in the Creative Computing Curriculum Guide (http://scratched.gse.harvard.edu/guide/) and I wanted to see how it might feel for a student to go through the activity on their own.

I changed the way the user manipulates the big fish (I thought it was awkward to use the mouse from a laptop), and added two new levels. I was trying to recreate a game that I loved when I was little (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dZUXImHsEIQ) for level 3.

There are still some buggy things (such as the creepy kind-of-dead-looking seagull), and I hope to come back to this project later to smooth them out!
instructions:
Guide the big fish with the arrow keys to eat the little fish. See how many little fish you can catch!

Level up at a score of 10, 20, and 30.

title: Know Your Mollusks! (Getting Unstuck, Day 8)
description:
For Day 8 of gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu

I had SO MUCH FUN making this. I was walking down the street with @jsh, when we saw a huge pile of abandoned mussels on the side of the road. I asked @jsh what they were and he said, "I don't really know my mollusks!" And thus a project was born!

I used counting in two ways in this project: to determine when the player has reached the target of 10 mollusks, and then to report out the count for each of the 3 types of mollusks at the end (if you win).

I searched for "harp music" on Scratch and found @lkaufm's "Irish Harp Interactive": https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/53006916/
I found the images from wikimedia, searching for "illustrations [harpist/cat/clam/etc.]".
instructions: Press the green flag to start. Then, correctly identify 10 mollusks!

title: Catch 'em all
instructions: Left and right arrow keys to move around, space to jump. Try to catch all the Pokemon. There are some surprise rare Pokemon that are worth more points! Also Team Rocket is lurking...if you run into them they'll steal your Pokemon!

title: Strong Cat
description:
This project was created for Day 8 of Getting Unstuck. The essence of today's challenge was to use a counter and make something happen when a particular number is reached. In this case, the counter represents raw feline strength, as expressed through your mouse clicks. 

Update: Now in black and white, for better ambiance. 

Music: James Scott, "Frog Legs Rag"; Scott Joplin, "The Entertainer"
instructions: Click the green circle and see what happens.

title: Playing with Plants!
description:
Thanks to:
eebeec for the plant sprite!
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/85226318/#player

I gave myself a challenge to not draw my own sprites. I couldn't find a fitting plant in the sprite library, and @paulinah suggested I take a look at other plant projects for sprites! I was delighted to find the base sprite for this plant by @eebeec! (I did let myself make some (relatively) small costume edits in the paint editor. (and I made the lil drop in the paint editor)

This is my first game (and my first time using clones!) and it was so much fun to make! This definitely feels like the kind of meeting of idea + challenge that I was aspiring for with yesterday's project. Maybe I need a Getting Unstuck strategy that's something like "Remember Not Every Project Will Feel Good (and they shouldn't!)" I probably am not taking risks if I love *everything* I make. I LOVE THIS GAME, THO!

That being said, I would like to play around with how much water the plant would like to have for healthy hydration (and the corresponding too dry/too wet feedback). I'd also like to add a "water level" meter.
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, press the space bar and use the left and right arrow to move the plant to catch water drops to keep the plant well-watered. Be careful not to over or under water!

What ideas do you have for continued work on the game? When playing, what are you wishing were part?

title: Magellan School Fitness Challenge (Unstuck 8)
description:
This is a remix of the Exploratorium's "Makey Makey Physical Fitness Challenge" from 2012 that incorported physical movement and computational tinkering. This one is specific to push-ups, but can be easily repurposed for just about any physical activity and part of a collaboration with our awesome PE coach for an upcoming unit in the fall.

Link to original blog:
https://tinkering.exploratorium.edu/tinkering/2012/06/15/makey-makey-physical-fitness-challenge

The most difficult part for me with this remix was figuring out how to prevent players from scoring points after the timer went off. After getting seriously stuck and getting help from a friend, we came up with a variable based on the game's state as either "on" or "off." Such a simple, powerful idea.
instructions:
For use with Makey Makey. To play: 
First, put on the conductive wristband, then touch the Start pad (Spacebar). After the dialogue is finished and the timer starts, do as many pushups as you can, making sure to touch the pads after each one (Right->Down->Up). Stop when you hear the buzzer. See if you can get the top score!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 8 — Concentric Circles
description:
Reflection

After starting on a few different ideas, I landed on creating a concentric circle generator that accepts input from the user via the slider. 

The process is simple. It stamps a circle, changes costume, reduces size, and repeats a number of times specified by the slider.

The number of circles that are drawn is stored in the nCircles variable. The slider feature of this variable enabled. Instead of drawing the concentric circles every frame, the script instead responds to when the value of nCircle changes. There's a note in the script that points to where this happens.

One feature that could be added is moving the center point of a stamped circle each iteration to generate images similar to Marcel Duchamp's Anémic Cinéma rotoreliefs.
instructions: Use the slider to change the number of concentric circles.

title: Just a little bit
description:
Getting Unstuck day-8
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I explain how counting is done in binary numbers.

For the "bit" I used a Sprite with 2 costumes (0 and 1). This Sprite has several local variables (its properties), such as its value (0 or 1), its position (0=least significative bit, 1=second signitificative bit, etc).

The Green Button increase the first bit, when a bit pass from 1 to 0 (overflow) it set the variable Destination to its Position+1 and send a broadcast message to all the sprites yelling "overflow!".
The bit that have the Position corresponding to the Destination (i.e. the bit at the left of the bit that raised the overflow) is then incremented and (if necessary) it can raise the overflow again...
So the global variable Destination is used to select which bit must respond to the broadcast message.

The number of bits is not fixed from the beginning (you start with just  1 bit). If a further bit is needed it is created by cloning the one who is about to raise the overflow.
A Lightening represent the overflow which propagates through the bits.
The global variable Count (showed at screen) counts in decimal number.
instructions:
*** Do you know how to count in binary?
*** Press the Green Button to increase the binary number shown!

At the beginning you have just a single bit 0, when you press the button it becomes 1, when you press the button again it cannon grow again (in binary the only symbols allowed are 0 and 1) and therefore it get back to 0 raising an Overflow (represented by the Lightening) to the bit at its left. If such a bit does not exist, it is created... so you can count from 0 to +Infinite in binary numbers!

title: savetheclocktower
description:
for Day 8 of GettingUnstuck, I'm tinkering a bit more with this project in preparation for a physical computing camp next week.

The speed of the vehicle in MPH is calculated at the second circuit point and published on screen. As a math dropout I'm always unsure of my calculations so I would appreciate feedback on these.

If the calculated speed is between 8 and 9 mph (a nod to the 88 mph benchmark established in Back to the Future), the background changes briefly.

PROBLEMS: 1) this calculates the average speed over a stretch of track, but is it possible to calculate speed at a specific location? One can shorten the gap between circuits but the conceptual problem remains. 2) Is there a threshold amount of time needed for makeymakey to recognize that a circuit has been completed? 3) Passing through the circuits slows the vehicle down, based on how I've engineered the wires. Is there a better way to engineer this so the vehicle isn't slowed down? 4) Can the program be improved, possibly by adding another circuit to the course, so that the slowdown at each circuit point is calculated, and the speed at the final circuit is suitably discounted? 5) Scratch's moonwalking isn't very good.
instructions:
v. 1 the beginning of a physical computing project to measure the speed of a matchbox car at a given point in space

Connect makeymakey up arrow and down arrow to two incomplete circuits on a hotwheels track, twelve inches apart. The car should pass through the up arrow circuit first. Configure a car with copper tape so the car can complete the circuits when passing through.

(Without makeymakey, simulate w/ flag, up arrow, down arrow.)

title: Unstuck 08 Frog Game
description:
This is a remix of a project I build with students over six to eight classes. I modified it for the Unstuck Challenge so the game changes when five flies are caught, so the project responds when the variable reaches a certain number. I didn't meet that condition in my first project post (coin flip simulator)

I had to significantly modify the script so the game would pause after five flies are caught. The modification changed the game play so now the frog moves much more quickly and smoothly since the move scripts are all inside a forever loop instead of separate <when ___ key is pressed> event blocks. This will be a great way to show students how different script solutions, both valid, create different experiences for the program users.

I suppose I could make this change after a certain amount of time passes using the timer variable instead...
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. 

Catch all ten flies as quickly as possible. 

Use the arrow keys to move the frog around the screen and press the space key to flick the frog's tongue and catch the flies.

title: Day 8
description:
music from https://emp3.direct.com

Wow! So many amazing projects in the studio! I was inspired by mizzpeters remix and also alirb plant project. I need some sort of intensive internal reprogramming myself so that I make one thing work and then do the next. For reasons?! I am always making everything at once and then it is a nightmare detangling clumps of code when I need to adjust one aspect. Spent eons trying to get the timer to cooperate - I still can't figure out why it won't shut down at 0!

Thanks to MrQuentin for explaining why my score counter was rocketing into the thousands! Also for acting as my game tester (I can't actually successfully play any video game - my students find this hilarious, but it makes it really hard to test the code and see if the game really works!), and showing me a better way to program the arrow keys!

title: Penguin Jumper Unstuck #8 & #12
description:
This project came from a book I bought at our Spring Book Fair. It's called "20 Games to Create With Scratch" by Max Waine Wright. 

I wanted to stretch my comfort level, especially since this project deals with variables. I've used variables for scoring, but not much else. I liked this idea because in addition to score it uses variables to set the speed and angle of the penguin. At first the game was too easy. All you had to do was point at the iceberg. I had to play around and tweak the speed and gap to get the penguin to launch at the angle I wanted.

I figured out how to add lives when a certain score is reached, but I'd like to be able to add a life at certain increments, for example at every multiple of 50. I'm sure it must be an easy math calculation, but I couldn't figure out how to do that. Any suggestions would be most appreciated.
instructions:
Click the green flag to begin. Aim the arrow and then click on it to send the penguin to the blue iceberg.

I added levels & scenes to this for Unstuck #12

title: Unstuck Day 8 - Variables
description: I enjoyed getting this one to work. Had issues with simultaneous "if touching" scripts not working, so made adjustments and put everything into one "if touching" statement on the mouse only.
instructions:
Challenge:
Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number. 

Click on the flag to begin. Watch as the cat begins to eat the mice and grow bigger and slower as it goes. Once reaching 10 mice, it will say "I am full!" and code will end.

title: Getting Unstuck 8
description:
This was a fun one. I like playing around with making things look animated. I still need to work on the details a bit so the cars don't drive into each other. I also learned that you can use the costume # as a variable, which made this a lot easier!

Some things I could add if I had time: fixing the animation as I mentioned, adding some sprites as scenery that will pass by as you drive, and playing with the rules so you lose points if you click on a car that's not blue. Also a soundtrack - I always overlook this (mostly because my computer is almost always on mute).

UPDATE: I added sound and it's so much better! Now I need to go back and incorporate sound into my earlier projects.
instructions: Click on the green flag to start. Click on the cars to count them - only count the blue ones!

title: Day 8 Getting Unstuck
description:
With a nod toward sharing and collaboration, I remixed this Day 2 project from another #GettingUnstuck participant and added a little code for the Day 8 challenge:
Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number.
instructions:
Click on the green flag to start or to clear any stamped flowers, then click the background to change van Gogh's wheat field into a field of flowers.

As you add more flowers, the wheat field darkens to black.

title: Bubble duck!!
description:
This game is based on the "Bomb Jack" game.
When I was a child I used to play it on my game boy a lot, so I have good memories about it.
I decided to use simple gravity when the character reaches the ground and a variable to control when it jumps.
The enemies moves differently in each level and I also have clones for the bubbles.

                                    ---Questions---
+What did you like most about your project? 
I think it is fun.

+What would you do with it next, if you had more time?
I'd like to add more levels, power-ups and enemies with different abilities.

---Credits---
+Music: sound effects and song are from scratch gallery.
+Game design: I've created characters, and other sprites with  the scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then press the play button.
Use the Left and Right arrow keys to move your player.
Use the Up arrow key to jump.
Get the bubbles and try to avoid the enemies.
You have 3 lives.
Good luck!!

                               ---Getting Unstuck Day 8---
Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number.

title: Unstuck Day 8
description: This was fun and challenging.
instructions: Use right and left arrow to move the mouse.  Eating the cheddar cheese gives you 1 point and the swiss cheese gives you 2.  If you get 50 points without being hit by the bowl of cheese puffs, you win.  If the cheese puffs hit you, the game is over and you loose.

title: Pop the balloons!
description:
Did you know that sprite variables are different for every clone of the sprite? I discovered by chance and now I always use them. That's useful for keeping track the energy of an enemy and other parameters of a single clone.
For example, if you are trying to simulate a snowy day, every snowflake can have a different falling speed. The starting value is inherited by the parent sprite, so you can randomize it and then create a clone.
In this project I used the parameter "inflate!" to keep track of a balloon's status. When the count is 3, the balloon is popped and a point is scored.

Credits to NFour for the inflating sound ( http://soundbible.com/1410-Inflating-Balloon.html ) and to Andeh Pinkard for Badonk-a-donk font ( https://www.dafont.com/badonk-a-donk.font )
instructions:
Click three times on the balloons, the third time the balloon will pop and you will score a point.
How many points are you able to get in a minute?

title: Unstuck Day 8: Make Counters Using Variables

To move Scratch, use arrow left, arrow right, or the up keys.

I was sort of annoyed at first, because I was trying to do something new, and I failed, but I did end up learning something new while making this, so all was not lost.
instructions: The Helicopter will follow your mouse as your chase clouds for points.

title: Bubbles Video Sensing remix: Getting Unstuck Day 8 Variables
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 8 Variables

I wasn't feeling this project today (because reasons) but I wanted to stick with it, so I decided to take the "easy way out" and remix another project. The reason I say that is that I always want to make my own thing and remixing someone else's work feels a bit like cheating, or at least a short cut. 
But I am convinced of the remix spirit. I was able to do more remixing this video in half an hour than I would have been able to do on my own. Using the video function of Scratch is a blast, and the simple bubble popping action was perfect to add a variable to and turn into a "game" that ends when you hit an arbitrary number. 
I was already fairly comfortable with variables, so it was great to use today's prompt to discover a different unknown aspect of Scratch.
instructions:
Pop the bubbles or just watch them float up the screen. 
(This requires a webcam. )
REMIX TIPS:
- Animate the bubble when it pops.
- Change where the bubbles come from.
- Keep track of how many bubbles have been popped.

title: The Royal Dice Theatre
description:
This project responds to the prompt for Getting Unstuck Day 8:  "Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number." 

Today's strategy was "Find a Tutorial" + Remix a Project."  I referred to Ch. 5 (Variables) in the book "Learn to Program with Scratch" by Majed Marji.  The book features starter projects that one can access online.  I followed instructions to build the project, then added more dice sprites, a Score variable, a new backdrop, costume, text, and sounds.  For info on the book, go to https://nostarch.com/learnscratch/ . (Not sure if there will be a revised edition for Scratch 3.0, but it's still a great resource!)
instructions: Click on the green flag to start, then click on the Queen's crown to start each round.  See if you can score 10 to receive a special message!

title: Untitled-56
description:
I've been tinkering with sound for the entire week, and I recently got very interested in understanding how synthesizers work, so I continued experimenting also with this (super experimental) project.

I wondered about ways to have a seamless transitions between notes. After more than 2 hours and thousands of experiments, I tried with two scripts calling each other using messages.

I was very surprised by the effect and I haven't quite understood how it works, but the code looks elegant and it sounds.. interesting! :) 
As you can hear, the sound still goes through some sort of stages. In my next experiments I will try to get to something more continuous.

I wanted to keep the stage minimal, so that people can concentrate on the sound. I kept the title as Untitled-56, as a reminder of the many attempts I made and the unfinished nature of this work.

Enjoy!
instructions: Make sure your volume is not too high and press the green flag!

Thank you to @Mittensbrother for inspiring my project. Your ideas are out of normal. I used the coding strategy for the variable waiting until 0 for something to happen and for my camera to take a picture until characters were ready. You cleared my mind!

Characters from different sources: Frida (Nicholas Muray) Cantinflas (sexenio.com.mx), El Santo (Devian art), El Chapulin (Wikia) Pedro Infante (La Bombilla), Camera (Canon)

I liked the idea of using the variable as a countdown for animating a silly bomb. I use variables all the time bc they are fun and give you flexibility in editing. 

I had fun uploading free sound effects I found on the internets.

I was inspired by a very silly James Veitch video I watched recently about being a bad roommate with duckies in a shared bathroom: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f5d8pVg3Qtg.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 8 Reflection:
This was fun to make.  I was excited when I finally figured out how to make something else happen when the variable reached 10.  That took longer than I thought.  If I had more time I'd want to figure out why my original ladybug stopped cooperating.  At first it moved and counted towards the total like the clones did, but I messed something up somewhere.  I just hid it in the end and added another clone to make the game work the way I wanted it to.  I'd also like to figure out a better way for the bugs to move.  My way is kind of a pain to catch and doesn't accurately portray how bugs move.
instructions: Click start and use the arrow keys so the bat can eat all of the bugs.

title: Unstuck - Day 8
description:
This project is just a variation of a traditional pong game.  We decided to count how many times the ball hits the Scratch Cat. When the score is greater than 10, then the ball moves faster. After 20 and 30 it also gets faster.  Each time the ball goes behind the cat, the score decreases by 1.  When the score is less than 1, the game is over.
Some modifications we plan to make include: 
-When the speed changes, the ball switched colors (changes costume)
-When the ball goes behind the cat, the score changes by -5, making the game a bit more challenging.
-Once the ball gets faster, it doesn't slow down (still haven't figured out how to do this - any suggestions?  I'm thinking maybe using If, then, else or set a range such as score > 10 and score <20)
-Have a timer that counts how long the player keeps playing.  When the game is over, the time is displayed.
-Anyone else have suggestions?
instructions:
Click Green Flag to Start.
Move your mouse up and down and try to hit the ball.
Try to keep up!

title: #GettingUnstuck8 - Random numbers and means
description:
All sprites and costumes taken from the Scratch repository.

This project can be easily optimized, but it is just a fast draft for the GettingUnstuck 8th challenge.
instructions:
Press green flag and follow the instructions. Keep space bar to finish the program.

This project generates 50 random numbers [1..100] each time and saves the results. It also calculates the mean of all numbers and saves it in a list (so you can check how it varies).

This project is part of #GettingUnstuck initiative #CreativeComputing, Day 8.

"Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number"

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8 - variables

Created for Getting Unstuck Day 8 using variables. This mini-game was inspired by my fight with the carpenter bees slowly killing the willow tree in my front yard.

The variables are the 30 second timer for the game duration and the score.

For some reason I always have trouble with the touch blocks to change the score. It seems that the program doesn't always sense that the sprites are touching.

Left and right arrows move the character
Press the space bar to jump

title: Fruit and Veggie Challenge
description:
Very loosely based on the classic video arcade game Pacman.

I reworked a previous project that I first created back in 2013.  I made some adjustments in this version - making the sprites smaller and hiding the sprites after they are chomped (I've always wanted to do that but never found the time to get around to it). I discovered that once I hid the sprites though, I had to go back and adjust my scoring variables because they were no longer on the screen to allow for a higher score. The game is a little bit trickier now, I think.  You have to chomp all five healthy foods (50 points) while avoiding unhealthy foods (so that you don't lose points). You have to get 50 points within 20 seconds to win.
instructions:
Click Green Flag to start.

Chomp  healthy fruits and veggies - You earn points
Stay away from unhealthy snacks (You lose points if you chomp them)

Chomp all healthy foods to earn 50 points to Win!  Good luck, you only have 20 seconds!

title: Unstuck 8: Melon Bounce
description: Credit: modified code from Coding in Scratch Games Workbook.
instructions:
Click the flag to start the game.
Cat has to stop the falling watermelons from hitting the ground, but he doesn't know where they'll appear or which melon will drop first. Help him to keep the melons in the air.
Each melon starts in a random position. The melons bounce off the cat and back up into the air.
Left key - moves the cat forward.
Right key - moves the cat in reverse direction. When a melon hits the bottom of the stage, you hear a cymbal, and it's the end of the game.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 8
description: When I originally started this project, I wanted to do a Frogger game for Scratch. Instead, I created something slightly different. I enjoyed how I was able to make the shrink and as it moves towards the city, it gives a sense of motion. If I had more time, I would have made the other Sprites disappear and reappear after the cat touches them.
instructions:
Click on green flag to start the program. Use the arrow keys to control the Scratch Cat. Note - as you move around, the cat will shrink - Try to get to 11 or more points before the Sprite disappears. After getting the required points, then swim to shore using the arrow keys.

I hope you enjoy the game.

title: Cat Lollipops (Unstuck #8)
description:
Day 8 of Getting Unstuck! Join us at gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu.

Our activity of the day: Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens—and responds when the count reaches a certain number.

This works with a List! (not variables, strictly speaking — but it does count and report variations, and respond to the count!)
instructions:
How many lollipops can one cat handle?

Press the green flag and then follow the story to find out!

title: Day 8 - Counting Game
description: This little game could easily be customized and expanded. You can add more hippos or change it to an addition game, etc. One problem I have that I would fix if I had more time, is that the hippos sometimes end up on top of each other.  I think this would be a great kindergarten game!
instructions: Click on the green arrow and then count the hippos. You can drag the hippos on the screen to make sure you see them all or to help you count them. When you get 3 answers correct, you win.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 8
description:
The challenge for Day 9 was: Using variables, create a project that counts the number of times something happens and responds when the count reaches a certain number.

My backdrop poses the question of "Can Scratch do 5 jumping jacks?".  Of course he can! When he does completes the 5 there is a clapping sound. I added a random block (given to us in the day 6 challenge) to have him complete a few extra jumps.  Of course I also have the counter on the bottom to keep track of how many jumping jacks he completes!
instructions:
Do you think that Scratch the Cat can do more than 5 jumping jacks?

Click the green arrow to see how many he can do!
Don't forget to give him props for completing his five!

title: Total Turtle Turn random angles--evolve into sprays
description:
Getting Unstuck - Day 8
"create a project that counts the number of times something happens—and responds when the count reaches a certain number"
This project has definitely evolved -- it began with walking around a circle, but with random turns -- checking the total until it reached or exceeded 360, then adjusting so that the final turn made the total 360. Thinking about turtle art and mathematical stitching, after a number of variations (from dots to colored lines), the randomly generated points of the turns are stored in lists, then the lists are stepped through to create the lines from the first point of each original path. The color changes for each design; shading changes step by step until the "floor" of the distance to the point is reached. (Hopefully this will make more sense if you happen to look at the code.)
instructions:
0. Green Flag = clear
1. Use slider to change the 'step-length' (optional)
2. Spacebar - generate one spray of design
3. Drag the cat to a new location

Repeat steps 1-3 to create your design
